keymaps.name: Dvorak for PC
keymaps.description: The Dvorak keyboard layout was designed with the goal of maximizing typing efficiency. This is the PC version.

keymaps.name: Empty
keymaps.description: Empty layout.

keymaps.name: Empty2
keymaps.description: Empty layout.

keymaps.name: Init
keymaps.description: Initialization layout. Press space to continue to default layout. Or Q/W/E/R/T for other layouts.

keymaps.name: Lock
keymaps.description:
If you don't wan't other people play with your keyboard, you may set this keymap as default. It will consume all keystrokes untill phrase 'letmein <enter>' is typed.

Obviously, Agent can still be used to both change and read the macro, so this is no way an actual security measure.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Base
keymaps.description:
Base layout.

Philosophy:
- Have all features from right side also available on left side. This way, you can have hour right hand on mouse all the time and type simple words, abbreviations etc with your left hand
- Layers are implemented via actual "Keymaps". Layers of those keymaps are used to implement layer "sub-features" such as mirroring of keyboard halves.
- We include an experimental VIM mode which fakes some of basic VIM functionality. Beware, some features are implemented while others are not. And even thos which are implemented may be misbehaving because the keyboard has to guess things like active selection.

Press:
- Case buttons for symmetric arrow cluster and easily accessible del/bcksp/home/end/pgDn/pgUp (Mirroring Mod Held).
- Both case buttons to lock arrow layer (Mirroring Mod Locked).
- A/s/semicolon as secondary role for symmetric mouse cluster.
- "Mouse" to mirror right half onto left half (the mirrored layouts are defined by actual mod layers in most of the partial keymaps).
- Tab to access right half special character column on left keyboard half.
- Z to access configuration toggles on right half and macro slots on left half.
- X to access debugger bindings (step over, step in, etc.).
- Left alt to access experimental VIM mode. 
- Fn or F for Fn layer and numpad.
- B+key for tmux bindings.

Non-intuitivities which need to be pointed out:
- For some applications you may need to disable alphabetic secondary keys. This may be done by case btn + b
- By default, left alt triggers experimental VIM mode. You can disable this via case btn+alt+alt sequence and reenable by case btn+alt+v

keymaps.name: Mirroring Dbg Qt
keymaps.description: Debugger bindings for QtCreator. Activate by x.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Fn
keymaps.description: Fn mode. Pretty much vanilla.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Half Mouse
keymaps.description: Experimental layout.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Half Musescore
keymaps.description:
This is an application-specific layer for MuseScore. 

Right half implements:
- note length on yuiop and dotted note length on 789.
- cursor keys on hjkl
- octave jumps on m,

keymaps.name: Mirroring Mod held
keymaps.description: Mod layer, containing various auxiliary functions (cursor keys, del, backspace, escape, enter, etc.). Can be activated by case buttons.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Mod locked
keymaps.description: Locked Mod layer aka cursor key layer - to be locked by activating both case buttons.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Mouse Mode
keymaps.description: Symmetric mouse mode with basic browser controls. Activate via a, s, or semicolon as secondary roles.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Mouse Mode Accel
keymaps.description: Experimental variant of the Mirroring Mouse Mode.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Parenthes Mode
keymaps.description: Special characters can be inputted via this layer. Activated as secondary by tab from base layer.

keymaps.name: Mirroring Tmux Mode
keymaps.description: Use B+key from base layer to control tmux.

keymaps.name: Mirroring VIM Mode
keymaps.description:
Experimental VIM mode for UHK.

Access via left Alt from base layer.
Press z+Alt+v on base layer to enable the mode.
Press z+Alt+Alt on base layer to disable the mode.
Press z+Alt+Esc on base layer to make alt send escape - to simulate vim's alt behaviour in fake VIM environments.

Only some subset of VIM functionality which is used by the creator of this layout is implemented. Even those things which are implemented may be misbehaving because UHK has to guess about your selection. E.g., shortcuts which activate selection set a "selection flag" and future commands behave according to this selection flag irrespectively of what you do with mouse.

keymaps.name: Mirroring X Mode
keymaps.description:
X mode contains macro slots on left half and used to contain configuration toggles on right half. X because I used to have it bound on x key for some time.

Press z+config option from base layer.
Press z+shift+key on base layer to start/stop recording macro.
Press z+key on base layer to replay macro.
Press z+number to select number of repetitions.

keymaps.name: QWERTY fallback
keymaps.description: This is a simple version of the complex Mirroring setup. E.g., contains working Mod mode and contains vim-homerow style arrow keys.

keymaps.name: QWERTY for PC
keymaps.description: QWERTY is the mother of all layouts. This is the PC version.

keymaps.name: QWERTY GAMING
keymaps.description: QWERTY is the mother of all layouts. This is the PC version.

keymaps.name: Test
keymaps.description: Testing layout.

macroActions.text:
1-9 reserved  to pass "arguments" in macro calls
10 toggle secodary home row
15 secondary homerow delay via resolveSecondary
17 secondary homerow safety margin delay
18 macro repetition register
20 selection flag - used whenever command expects "selection command" as argument
21 toggle vim mode - toggles various VIM activation styles 
22 visual mode flag - denotes that VIM_V macro is active and holds shift
23 stop search mode flag register - used for Ctrl+f <-> enter.
24 doubleshift register
25 "selection is active" flag - set by vim commands depending on their context
26 select type - 1 = line, 0 = word. If we know that full line was selected, yank ebhaves according to it.
27 recording flag - if set, recording macros in X mode should start/stop recording
28 "super" flag - denoting pressed soft super
29 reverse search flag
$ifRegEq 25 1 break //this means that we have already selected *something*
$setReg 25 1 //lets assume that selection mode always selects something
$ifRegEq 25 1 break //this means that we have already selected *something*
$setReg 25 1 //lets assume that selection mode always selects something
$noOp //wait for visual mode macro to finish
$ifRegEq 29 1 ifRegEq 18 0 setReg 18 1 //ifReverse search, correct automatic forward jump
$ifShift setReg 26 1 //but if shift is pressed, it is line mode
